Woman dies in Baltimorean fire
By Members of the Staff
Ann Baker, a 50 year old
Baltimorean apartment house
dweller, died Monday morning
after apparently setting fire to
her third-floor apartment. Johns
Hopkin University had
Purchased the Baltimorean last
fall, and issued eviction notices
to all tenants.
Pinkerton security guard John
Pllugard first smelled smoke at
approximately 3:30 a.m.
Yesterday. He struggled fo open
Baker's door, but accumulated
trash and a propped-up stick
prevented his entrance.
Firefighteis broke into the
room at 4:00 a.m. after Pflugard
had summoned them. Her body
Was found on top of a six-foot
high pile of smoldering trash.
Chief Thomas Sisk of the
Baltimore Fire Department
Investigation Team said, "It was
a probable suicide. No note was
left, but the conditions
surrounding the incident led us
to believe that it was a suicide."
Baker had lived in the
apartment house for thirteen
Years. The last of forty
Baltimorean tenants to remain in
the building, she was scheduled
for eviction last Friday. Hopkins
had sent the 60-day notice last
February.
During her residence. Baker

was known as a recluse who only
talked to visitors with her door
slightly opened. She reportedly
saw only one person (Rev. Wayne
Welch, a former University
minister), in her tenancy.
James Price, a former
employee at Greenway
Pharmacy, said that the woman
received small containers of milk
and packages of cookies three or
four times a week; however, he
had never seen more than her
arm reaching out of the door to
receive the food.
The previous Baltimorean
management rarely disturbed her;
they had skipped her room
during all scheduled paintings.
Peter Heist, Director of
University Housing, said that
while Hopkins officials were
worried that Baker would have
difficulty in transferring to a new
residence, they thought "she had
taken things in hand." The
woman told Heist that she .had
made arrangements to live
temporarily in the Lan Dea Motel
Apartments on York Road,
before moving to Florida.
Heist indicated that at no time
did the woman issue an
ultimatum" or imply in any way
that she might take her life.
Several of the Baltimorean's
tenants told WBAL-TV that
Baker "didn't want to leave."

The former manager said, "I
don't think Ann Baker is going to
leave this place."
Over the weekend, Heist made
repeated phone calls to Baker. He
understood that Baker intended
to leave the premises Monday
morning. Recognizing the
possibility that the woman would
not leave then, he had intended
to retain the services, of a
professional social service agent
to assist in her departure. Heist %.
also assigned Pflugrad to check -z
on Baker every fifteen minutes, -0
even though he finally believed
that she would leave in the
morning as scheduled.

Taxi Driver and Alice will have
an opportunity tonight to see

director comes from. The Film

Scorsese's works to date, Mean
Streets was judged the best film
of the eleventh New York Film
Festival and provoked Pauline
Kael to call it "a true original of
our period. . . a blood thriller in
the truest sense."
Harvey Keitel plays the
anti-hero loosely based on
Scorsese's own memories of
growing up in Little Italy, a
portrait of the film-maker as
young mafioso. Robert De Niro
won the New York Film Critics'
Award for his bravura
performance as the flamboyant
foil to Keitel's cautious hood.
Scorsese's camera explores with
extraordinary fluidity the gritty,
lurid world of their cut-rate
inferno, bounded by the Bowery,
Chinatown, and the
Village
From the opening tracking shot

of the neighborhood bar to the
harrowing last minutes of gun
play, the director keeps the film
close to the taste and feel of the
mean streets that the taxi driver
cruises through. The operatic
force of the pop soundtrack and
the vitality of De Niro's
performance help to focus the
improvisatory technique of the
acting.
Funny
Despite the grit and the gore,
. Mean Streets is a very funny
film, with familiar types caught
from absurd angles. Without
impeding the action, Scorsese
manages to explore a theme
never completely achieved in The
Godfather—the complex
psychological play between
baroque religiosity and "family"
crime. Joseph Gelmis touches on
some of the Dantesque lights in
the film: "Marty Scorsese is a
major talent. His cameras can
make a stroll through a garish bar
look like a tour of hell, with the
damned fouls brawling, boozing,
even killing each other. Yet
Scorsese's art illuminates the
experience, makes it an
epiphany, rather than a sermon."

and irony of such a quest in our
society. Dr. Marty spoke of the
American experience as having
been molded by heterogeneous
social and religious groups with
little attention given to tradition.
He cited five dimensions which
have shaped the American nation
both religiously and spiritually:
pluralism, experimentalism,
scripturalism, the Enlightenment,
and voluntaryism. Stating that
our heritage has been one of
"change under principles of
non-change," he quoted the
famous French observer of the
American "experiment"
Alexander de Tocqueville: "there
exists a singular fixity of certain

principles...they love change but
dread revolution."
Though he viewed
scripturalism as a dynamic force
governing innovation, he did
warn of "constrictive norms"
which have resulted in "the
Indian being wiped out and the
black man enslaved." While each
religious sect who immigrated to
America came with the notion
that they had "the script," Dr.
Marty found "substantial shifts"
as evidenced by the separation of
church and ,state.
!Directions
Looking into the future, he
saw two possible directions for
movement, both departing from
the American credo "e pluribus
un urn." The first is a
"disparaging of variety, plures,
and a working toward unum"
ending in a "planned society"
with substantial loss of freedoms
now taken for granted. The other
and more likely possibility,
according to Dr. Marty, is a

"meaningless individualism...a
religion of high-rise apartments."
In this latter society, there will
be a "loss of power of
intermediate associations and
supportive groups, the school,
the family, and the church." This
"do your own thing"- philosophy,
he pointed out, is easily
observable today.
Remaining "cautiously
cptimistic," Dr. Marty proposed
that, "we accept as the heart of
our tradition, the part of
scriptures which speaks to us in
the present, e pluribus unum, a
community of subcommittees—a
freedom which avails us to work
together."
Following the lecture, he was
asked to assess the trend toward
mixing politics and religion in
this Presidential election year.
Rather than having these entities
insulated from one another, Dr.
Marty welcomed what he
referred to as "meddling" as a
healthy sign.

an opportunity tonight to see

director comes from. The Film

Scorsese's works to date, Mean
Streets was judged the best film
of the eleventh New York Film
Festival and provoked Pauline
Kael to call it "a true original of
our period. . . a blood thriller in
the truest sense."
Harvey Keitel plays the
anti-hero loosely based on
Scorsese's own memories of
growing up in Little Italy, a
portrait of the film-maker as
young mafioso. Robert De Niro
won the New York Film Critics'
Award for his bravura
performance as the flamboyant
foil to Keitel's cautious hood.
Scorsese's camera explores with
extraordinary fluidity the gritty,
lurid world of their cut-rate
inferno, bounded by the Bowery,
Chinatown, and the
Village
From the opening tracking shot

of the neighborhood bar to the
harrowing last minutes of gun
play, the director keeps the film
close to the taste and feel of the
mean streets that the taxi driver
cruises through. The operatic
force of the pop soundtrack and
the vitality of De Niro's
performance help to focus the
improvisatory technique of the
acting.
Funny
Despite the grit and the gore,
. Mean Streets is a very funny
film, with familiar types caught
from absurd angles. Without
impeding the action, Scorsese
manages to explore a theme
never completely achieved in The
Godfather—the complex
psychological play between
baroque religiosity and "family"
crime. Joseph Gelmis touches on
some of the Dantesque lights in
the film: "Marty Scorsese is a
major talent. His cameras can
make a stroll through a garish bar
look like a tour of hell, with the
damned fouls brawling, boozing,
even killing each other. Yet

experience, makes it an
epiphany, rather than a sermon."

Diamondmen finish season with three wins
By DAVID KRAUS
The Blue Jay baseball team
continued its winning ways with
consecutive victories in its three
most recent contests.
Last Thursday, Hopkins
downed Charles St. rival Loyola,
6-4, while on Saturday, the Jays
swept an important MAC
divisional twin-bill from
Washington College, 1-0 and 4-1.
The Hopkins nine now holds
an overall record of 11-6,
including a final mark of 7-3 in
MAC competition ("our best
MAC record ever," according to
Coach Dennis Cox), and has an
outside chance for post-season
play.
Loyola jumped out to an early
lead in Thursday's game. The
visiting Greyhounds tallieJ twice
in the top of the first inning, a
two-run double causing most of
the damage.
The Jays struck back in the
bottom of the third.
Designated-hitter Rick Scott
walked to lead off, and, one out
later, moved to second as Lou
Podrazik collected the first of his
four singles.
Dave Lewing followed with a
one-base hit, scoring Scott and
seonding Podrazik to third.
Lewing promptly stole second
and both runners eventually
crossed the plate on Tom
Pedroni's two-out, two-run single
as the Jays took a 3-2 lead.
Hopkins increased its
advantage to 5-2 with lone runs
in both the fourth and fifth
innings. In the fourth, Jim Duffy
singled, moved to second as Greg
Jenkins walked and scored as
Podrazik lined a base-hit to left.
A double by Bob Babb and a
single by Pedroni produced the
fifth-frame tally.
The visitors to Homewood
closed the gap in the top of the
sixth. A double, a two-base error,
and a single pulled Loyola to
within one run at 5-4, but that

was as close as the score would
become.
The Blue Jays added an
insurance run in the bottom of
the seventh as Podrazik singled,
moved to third on a base-hit by
Lewing and scored on Babb's
sacrifice fly.
Steffan Burns enabled the 6-4
lead to stand up with a fine
effort on the mound. The
freshman hurled a complete
game, allowing only five hits and
retiring, in order, the last seven
batters he faced.
The first game of Saturday's
doubleheader proved to be the
classic pitcher's duel. The
protagonists in this contest were
Billy Jones of Hopkins and
Dennis Compton of Washington.
Through the first four innings
of the game, neither pitcher
allowed a base-hit. The visiting
Shomen finally broke the spell
with a pair of singles in the top
of the fifth, but Jones was able
to easily subdue this Washington
scoring effort.
The Jays got their first safeties
of the afternoon in the bottom
of the sixth, but also proved
unable to score and the game
moved into the seventh inning.
As each contest in a
doubleheader is only a regulation
seven innings, extra frames
became a distinct possibility.
However, Hopkins eliminated
that chance in the bottom of the
seventh. Dave Emala was hit by a
pitched ball and then moved up
to second on a wild pitch.
Following a walk to Duffy, Scott
grounded a single to left,
enabling Emala to score and thus
ending the game.
Each of the pitchers ended up
having surrendered only three
hits. Jones, however, had the
superior outing, striking out nine
and giving up no walks.
The Jays did not wait quite as
long to decide the second game.
Singles by Babb, Emala, Lewing.

and Duffy produced three runs
and proved to be all of the
offense that was needed.
Meanwhile, Hopkins hurlers

Chuck Lachenbruch and Billy
Jones (working in relief)
combined to hole the visitors to
two hits and one unearned run.
